{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox company |name = Disney Theatrical Productions Ltd. |logo = [[File:Disney Theatrical Productions logo.svg|170px]] |type = Division of [[Disney Theatrical Group]] (former: Subsidiary corporation) |founder =[[Ron Logan]] |parent = [[Disney Theatrical Group]], Limited
([[Walt Disney Studios (division)|The Walt Disney Studios]]) |foundation = {{start date and age|1993}} |location_city = [[New York City]] |location_country = United States |key_people = [[Thomas Schumacher]] (President) |industry = Theater |products = [[Theatre|Productions]] |divisions = |homepage = {{URL|disneyonbroadway.com}} }} '''Disney Theatrical Productions Limited''' (DTP), also known as '''Disney on Broadway''', is the flagship [[stage (theatre)|stageplay]] and [[musical theater|musical]] production company of the [[Disney Theatrical Group]], a subsidiary of [[The Walt Disney Studios (production company)|The Walt Disney Studios]], a major business unit of [[The Walt Disney Company]]. Founded in 1993 by longtime Disney Entertainment veteran [[Ron Logan]] as '''Walt Disney Theatrical''', the division has gained a reputation within the industry for creating professional and popular (both critically and financially) performances, starting with the acclaimed ''[[Beauty and the Beast (musical)|Beauty and the Beast]]'' in April 19th, 1994 and most recently with ''[[The Jungle Book (1967 film)|The Jungle Book]]'' in September 23rd, 2019. The company is a division of [[Disney Theatrical Group]], led by [[Thomas Schumacher]]. ==History== Walt Disney Theatrical Production, Ltd. (DTP) was formed on {{dts|1993|2|8}}{{cite web|title=Buena Vista Theatrical Group Ltd.|url=http://appext20.dos.ny.gov/corp_public/CORPSEARCH.ENTITY_INFORMATION?p_nameid=1771511&p_corpid=1700823&p_entity_name=Disney%20Theatrical%20Productions&p_name_type=%25&p_search_type=BEGINS&p_srch_results_page=0|website=Business Entity search|publisher=New York Secretary of State|accessdate=July 31, 2015}} with [[Ron Logan]], Disney Park's live production head, as president to produce ''[[Beauty and the Beast (musical)|Beauty and the Beast]]''.{{cite news|last1=Wilson|first1=Paige|title=UCF Rosen professor a window into Walt Disney World|url=http://www.centralfloridafuture.com/story/entertainment/2015/02/04/ucf-rosen-professor-window-walt-disney-world/22876635/|accessdate=August 10, 2015|work=Central Florida Future|publisher=Gannett|date=February 4, 2015}} ''Beauty and the Beast'' opened on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] at the [[Palace Theatre (New York City)|Palace Theatre]] on {{dts|1994|4|18}}. Disney Theatrical signed a 49-year revenue based lease for [[New Amsterdam Theatre]] in {{dts|1995|5}}. The building was renovated by [[Disney Development Company]].{{cite news |last1=Kennedy |first1=Shawn G.|last2=Lesser|first2=Ellen C.|title=Disney and Developer Are Chosen To Build 42d Street Hotel Complex|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/05/12/nyregion/disney-and-developer-are-chosen-to-build-42d-street-hotel-complex.html|accessdate=July 30, 2015|work=New York Times|date=May 12, 1995|page=B2|quote= Disney has signed a 49-year lease to the 92-year-old New Amsterdam Theater, though it can get out of the deal by July 15 if certain conditions are not met. }} With ''[[The Lion King]]'' under consideration for the next Broadway adaption, Eisner ceded DTP to theatre-rooted Disney Animation president [[Peter Schneider (film executive)|Peter Schneider]] and [[Thomas Schumacher]], at their request, making them president and executive vice president of DTP respectively. In 1997, DTP re-opened the New Amsterdam Theatre with ''[[King David (musical)|King David]]'' followed by ''[[The Lion King (musical)|The Lion King]]'' musical.{{cite news|last1=Singer|first1=Barry|title=Theater; Just Two Animated Characters, Indeed|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/04/theater/theater-just-two-animated-characters-indeed.html?ref=topics|accessdate=August 10, 2015|work=New York Times|date=October 4, 1998}} Peter Schneider was promoted to [[The Walt Disney Studios (division)|Disney Studios]] president in January 1999, while Thomas Schumacher was promoted to president of [[Walt Disney Animation Studios|Walt Disney Feature Animation]] and Walt Disney Theatrical Productions, while both are made co-presidents of Disney Theatrical.{{cite news|authorlink1=Robert Simonson|last1=Simonson|first1=Robert|title=Thomas Schumacher Promoted to Co-President of Disney Theatricals |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/thomas-schumacher-promoted-to-co-president-of-disney-theatricals-79402 |accessdate= July 28, 2015 |work=Playbill|date=January 12, 1999}} On {{dts|1999|11|23}}, the corporate name was changed to [[Buena Vista (brand)|Buena Vista]] Theatrical Group Limited, with Disney Theatrical Productions becoming a division of the group with the formation of Hyperion Theatricals in {{dts|2000|1}}.{{cite news|title=Disney Creates New Theatre Division, Hyperion Theatricals|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/disney-creates-new-theatre-division-hyperion-theatricals-86793|accessdate=July 28, 2015|work=Pay Bill|date=January 31, 2000}} Schneider left Disney Theatrical in June 2001 to form his own theater production company partly funded by Disney.{{cite news|last1=Lyman|first1=Rick|title=Chairman of Disney's Studios Resigns to Return to Broadway|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/06/21/business/chairman-of-disney-s-studios-resigns-to-return-to-broadway.html|accessdate=August 10, 2015|work=New York Times|date=June 21, 2001}} His first project was developing and directing the ''[[Sister Act (musical)|stage version of Sister Act]]'' with Michael Reno. The musical had its official world premiere on November 3, 2006 at the Pasadena Playhouse, with DTP as an associated presenter during its Broadway run.{{cite news|last1=Hernandez|first1=Ernio|title=Sister Act — Musical Based on Film — Opens World-Premiere Run Nov. 3|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/sister-act-musical-based-on-film-opens-world-premiere-run-nov.-3-136055|accessdate=August 15, 2015|work=Pallbill|date=November 3, 2006}}{{cite news|last1=Isherwood|first1=Charles|title=Different Church, More Sequins|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/21/theater/reviews/sister-act-comes-to-broadway-review.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=August 15, 2015|work=New York Times|date=April 20, 2011}} ''[[Freaky Friday (musical)|Freaky Friday]]'' musical was developed by Disney Theatrical Productions from the book and Disney films for theatres to license. The musical premiered in October 2016 at Signature Theatre in Arlington, Virgina followed by three other threatre productions.{{cite news |last1=Rothstein |first1=Mervyn |title=What To Expect from Freaky Friday the Musical |url=http://www.playbill.com/article/what-to-expect-from-freaky-friday-the-musical |accessdate=October 24, 2018 |work=Playbill |date=October 4, 2016 |language=en}} Coinciding with the release of the [[Disney Channel Original Movie]] adaptation, a one-act version of the stage musical (based on the adaptation) was made available on August 10, 2018 for licensing.{{cite web |last1=Gans |first1=Andrew |title=Freaky Friday Musical Will Be Available for Licensing Through MTI |url=http://www.playbill.com/article/freaky-friday-musical-will-be-available-for-licensing-through-mti |website=Playbill |accessdate=August 16, 2018 |language=en |date=June 27, 2018}} Disney Theatrical Productions' ''Newsies'' debuted in cinemas on February 19, 2017.{{cite news|title=Disney's Tony Award-Winning Musical NEWSIES to Make Australian and New Zealand Cinema Debut|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/australia-melbourne/article/Disneys-Tony-Award-Winning-Musical-NEWSIES-to-Make-Australian-and-New-Zealand-Cinema-Debut-20161205|accessdate=January 7, 2017|work=BroadwayWorld.com|date=December 5, 2016}} == Animation adaptations == ===''Beauty and the Beast''=== {{main|Beauty and the Beast (musical)}} The show began previews in New York City on March 9, 1994 and officially opened at the [[Palace Theatre, New York|Palace Theatre]] on April 18, 1994. The musical was the first Broadway adaptation by [[Disney]], based on the [[Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)|1991 animated film]] by [[Linda Woolverton]] and with music and lyrics by [[Alan Menken]], [[Howard Ashman]] and [[Tim Rice]]. Several new songs were written for the Broadway musical, including ''Home'', a ballad sung by [[Belle (Disney)|Belle]] which quickly became the signature song of the musical. It ran until July 29, 2007 at the [[Lunt-Fontanne Theatre]], to make room for another Disney production, ''[[The Little Mermaid (musical)|The Little Mermaid]]''. At 5,461 performances, the show is currently the ninth-longest run in Broadway history. It has been performed internationally first in Melbourne, Australia and has also been performed in [[West End theatre|London]], [[Vienna]], Toronto, [[Kyoto]], [[Seoul]], [[Stuttgart]], Sydney, [[Mexico City]], [[Guayaquil]], [[Johannesburg]], Madrid, Moscow, [[Milan]], [[Sao Paulo]] and has also toured around the USA and United Kingdom. In the Netherlands this production was co-produced by [[Joop van den Ende]]'s [[Stage Entertainment]] with new sets and costumes. ===''The Lion King''=== {{main|The Lion King (musical)}} [[Image:Hamburg Musicaltheater.jpg|right|250px|thumb|''The Lion King'' followed ''[[Buddy – The Buddy Holly Story]]'' at the "Theater im Hafen", Hamburg. The theatre was completely renovated, by Stage Entertainment, before ''The Lion King'' transferred to Germany.]] The show debuted July 8, 1997, in Minneapolis, Minnesota at the Orpheum Theatre, before premiering on Broadway at the New Amsterdam Theater on October 15, 1997 in previews with the official opening on November 13, 1997. On June 13, 2006, the Broadway production moved to the Minskoff Theatre to make way for the musical version of ''Mary Poppins'', which later was replaced by ''Aladdin''.http://www.broadway.com/shows/aladdin-broadway/#loc=c-tab1-pos22 It is now Broadway's third longest-running show in history. The show uses a range of theatrical techniques, and is not a conventional musical. It has consistently been one of the highest grossing musicals on Broadway every week. The production won the [[Tony Award for Best Musical]] at the 1998 [[Tony Awards]] making it the first, and only, Disney musical to win. Its popularity has spawned several additional opening performances around the world, including in London, Toronto, Hamburg, Scheveningen, Sydney, Perth, Melbourne, Shanghai, Montreal, Tokyo, Paris, Nagoya, Russia, Seoul, Johannesburg, Las Vegas, Taipei, Tempe, Phoenix, Scottsdale, Mesa, Flagstaff, Madrid, Norway, Italy, Arabia, Gilbert, Scottsdale, Mexico City, Nepal, Finland, Switzerland and São Paulo. === ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'' === {{main|The Hunchback of Notre Dame (musical)}} In 2008, [[Stephen Schwartz (composer)|Stephen Schwartz]] said, "I think we're starting up ''Hunchback of Notre Dame'', hopefully, next year (2009). Rumor has reached my ear that it's happening."[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/114214.html Playbill.com Interview] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090408223817/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/114214.html |date=April 8, 2009 }} Thomas Schumacher, head of Disney Theatrical, discussed current and future stage productions in an article published by the ''[[Columbus Dispatch]]'' on September 21, 2008, including an English-language production of Hunchback.[http://www.columbusdispatch.com/live/content/life/stories/2008/09/21/1A_DISNEY_MUSICALS.ART_ART_09-21-08_E1_18BAF84.html?sid=101 Columbus Dispatch Article by Michael Grossberg] The musical had its US premiere at [[La Jolla Playhouse]] from October 28 through December 7, 2014. The production was directed by Scott Schwartz and the creative team includes Chase Brock as the choreographer, Michael Kosarin as the music supervisor and arranger, Michael Starobin as the orchestrator, Alexander Dodge as the scenic designer, Alejo Vietti as the costume design Howell Binkley as the lighting designer, and Gareth Owen as the sound design. ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'' had a workshop in February 2014.http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/BREAKING-DISNEYS-HUNCHBACK-OF-NOTRE-DAME-to-Have-US-Premiere-at-La-Jolla-Playhouse-20140124http://www.broadway.com/buzz/174220/into-the-california-sunlight-disneys-the-hunchback-of-notre-dame-will-have-its-us-premiere-at-la-jolla/ The La Jolla Playhouse production transferred to the [[Paper Mill Playhouse]] from March 4 through April 5, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://playbill.com/news/article/188119-Paper-Mill-Season-Will-Feature-Can-Can-Hunchback-Ever-After-Vanya-and-Sonia-and-More?tsrc=hpt2 |title=Paper Mill Season Will Feature Can-Can, Hunchback, Ever After, Vanya and Sonia and More |publisher=playbill.com |date=February 26, 2014 |accessdate=February 26, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140302173902/http://playbill.com/news/article/188119-Paper-Mill-Season-Will-Feature-Can-Can-Hunchback-Ever-After-Vanya-and-Sonia-and-More?tsrc=hpt2 |archivedate=March 2, 2014 |df= }}[http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Patrick-Page-Michael-Arden-Ciara-Renee-More-to-Lead-THE-HUNCHBACK-OF-NOTRE-DAME-at-La-Jolla-Playhouse-20140904 Patrick Page, Michael Arden, Ciara Renee & More to Lead THE HUNCHBACK OF NOTRE DAME at La Jolla Playhouse!] Broadway World, September 4, 2014 In 2017, the German version, with the same set decor, is playing in Berlin and München, Germany. In 2018, this production will transfer to Stuttgart. ===''Tarzan''=== {{main|Tarzan (musical)}} The show was based on the [[Tarzan (1999 film)|movie of the same name]] and the novel ''[[Tarzan of the Apes]]'' by [[Edgar Rice Burroughs]], and debuted on Broadway on May 10, 2006 at the [[Richard Rodgers Theatre]]. The show was heavily publicized with [[Phil Collins]] and the lead actors promoting the new musical on several media shows including ''[[Today (NBC program)|The Today Show]]'', ''[[Good Morning America]]'', and ''[[Live with Regis and Kelly]]''. After playing at the [[Richard Rodgers Theatre]] for over a year the show closed on July 8, 2007.{{cite news |title=Disney's 'Tarzan' to close July 8 on Broadway |work=[[USA Today]] |date= June 24, 2007 |accessdate=April 20, 2009 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/theater/news/2007-06-23-tarzan_n.htm }} On April 15, 2007, the musical debuted in Europe in the [[Netherlands]] as the successor of ''[[The Lion King (musical)|The Lion King]]'' in [[Scheveningen]]. A Broadway musical had never previously arrived in the Netherlands so soon after its Broadway [[premiere]]. [[Phil Collins]] was a special guest at the 2006 [[:nl:John Kraaijkamp Musical Award|Johnny Kraaijkamp Musical Award]] s, where he announced the news that Tarzan was coming to the Netherlands. Due to the size of the Circustheater, the show was expanded beyond the original Broadway production. In 2008, a new production opened in Germany. A casting show on TV called "Ich Tarzan, Du Jane" ("I Tarzan, you Jane") searched for actors for the roles of Tarzan and Jane. A revamped tour version had previously been announced to debut in January 2009 in [[Atlanta]] at the Theatre of the Stars. The new production was supposed to feature the same music and book, and directed and choreographed by Lynne Taylor-Corbett, with scenic design by Kenneth Foy, aerial design by Paul Rubin and lighting design by Ken Billington.{{cite news|last=Gans |first=Andrew |title=Revamped Tarzan Will Debut in January 2009 in Atlanta |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/114006.html |publisher=Playbill.com |date=2008-01-04 |accessdate=2008-01-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080105222000/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/114006.html |archivedate=January 5, 2008 |df= }} The production was ultimately cancelled.{{cite news|last=Hetrick |first=Adam |title=American Musical Theatre of San Jose Cancels Productions of 42nd Street, Tarzan and Closes Doors |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/123849.html |publisher=Playbill.com |date=2008-12-01 |accessdate=2008-12-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081205040548/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/123849.html |archivedate=December 5, 2008 |df= }} ===''The Little Mermaid''=== {{main|The Little Mermaid (musical)}} The musical began Broadway previews on November 3, 2007 and opened on January 10, 2008 at the [[Lunt-Fontanne Theatre]], even through trouble due to the [[2007 Broadway stagehand strike|Local One stagehands strike]], which ended on November 28, 2007. The world premiere took place at The [[Ellie Caulkins Opera House]] at the Denver Center of the Performing Arts in Denver, Colorado. The show features every song from the movie, as well as nine new songs written by Menken and lyricist [[Glenn Slater]]. The book was written by Pulitzer Prize and Tony Award-winning playwright [[Doug Wright]], with direction by [[Francesca Zambello]], choreography by [[Stephen Mear]], scenic design by [[George Tsypin]], costume design by Tatiana Noginova and lighting design by [[Natasha Katz]]. The musical on Broadway opened to mixed reviews. The original Broadway cast featured [[Sierra Boggess]] as [[Ariel (The Little Mermaid)|Ariel]], [[Norm Lewis]] as [[Characters of Disney's The Little Mermaid#King Triton|King Triton]], [[Sherie Rene Scott]] as [[Ursula (The Little Mermaid)|Ursula]], Eddie Korbich as [[Characters of Disney's The Little Mermaid#Scuttle|Scuttle]], [[Sean Palmer]] as [[Prince Eric]], Brian D'Addario and Major Curda as [[Characters of Disney's The Little Mermaid#Flounder|Flounder]], and Tituss Burgess as [[Sebastian (The Little Mermaid)|Sebastian]]. The musical closed on August 30, 2009 after 685 performances and 50 previews.[https://archive.is/20130104131745/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/130725] In 2012, a Dutch production premiered.{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} ===''Aladdin''=== {{main|Aladdin (2011 musical)}} In November 2010, [[Alan Menken]] confirmed that a musical theatre adaptation of the show is in the works with a book written by [[Chad Beguelin]].[http://broadwayworld.com/article/BWW_EXCLUSIVE_Alan_Menken_Talks_TANGLED_SISTER_ACT_LEAP_HUNCHBACK_ALADDIN_More_201115_page1 BWW EXCLUSIVE: Alan Menken Talks TANGLED, SISTER ACT, LEAP OF FAITH, HUNCHBACK, ALADDIN & More] The show premiered at the [[5th Avenue Theatre]] in [[Seattle]] from July 7 to July 31, 2011.[http://broadwayworld.com/article/Seattles_5th_Avenue_Theatre_Premieres_ALADDIN_7731_20110113 Seattle's 5th Avenue Theatre Premieres ALADDIN, 7/7-31] Another production played at the [[The Muny|Muny Theatre]] in [[St. Louis]] from July 5 – 13, 2012.[http://broadwayworld.com/article/ALADDIN-CHICAGO-DREAMGIRLS-et-al-Set-for-Muny-2012-Season-20111008 ALADDIN, CHICAGO, DREAMGIRLS et al. Set for Muny 2012 Season][http://www.muny.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&layout=blog&id=103&Itemid=100429 2012 Muny Season] The musical premiered on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] on February 26, 2014 (in previews) and officially on March 20, 2014 at the [[New Amsterdam Theatre]], taking the place of ''[[Mary Poppins (musical)|Mary Poppins]]'', which closed on March 3, 2013.Hetrick, Adam. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/181617-Disneys-Aladdin-Will-Arrive-on-Broadway-in-February-2014 "Disney's 'Aladdin' Will Arrive on Broadway in February 2014"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130901002722/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/181617-Disneys-Aladdin-Will-Arrive-on-Broadway-in-February-2014 |date=September 1, 2013 }} playbill.com, August 29, 2013[http://popwatch.ew.com/2013/01/08/disney-aladdin-broadway/ Disney's 'Aladdin' to seek a whole new world on Broadway][http://broadwayworld.com/article/Rialto-Chatter-ALADDIN-to-Hit-Broadway-Spring-of-2014-with-Major-New-Player-on-Creative-Team-20130108 Rialto Chatter: ALADDIN to Hit Broadway Spring of 2014 with 'Major New Player' on Creative Team][http://playbill.com/news/article/173764-Disneys-Aladdin-May-Fly-Into-Broadways-New-Amsterdam-Theatre-Following-Mary-Poppins Disney's Aladdin May Fly Into Broadway's New Amsterdam Theatre Following Mary Poppins] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714210540/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/173764-Disneys-Aladdin-May-Fly-Into-Broadways-New-Amsterdam-Theatre-Following-Mary-Poppins |date=July 14, 2014 }} The musical had a pre-Broadway tryout at the [[Ed Mirvish Theatre]] in [[Toronto]] lasting from November 13, 2013 to January 12, 2014.{{webarchive |url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20041114105226/http%3A//www.broadwayworld.com/ |title=Breaking News: Disney's ALADDIN to Play Pre-Broadway Tryout in Toronto Starting November 2013; Broadway Spring 2014 |date=2004-11-14}} [[Casey Nicholaw]] directed and choreographed, with [[Chad Beguelin]] writing the book and additional lyrics, [[Bob Crowley]] as the scene designer, and costume design by [[Gregg Barnes]].[http://playbill.com/news/article/174280-Disneys-Aladdin-Will-Play-Toronto-This-Fall-Prior-to-2014-Broadway-Premiere Disney's Aladdin Will Play Toronto This Fall Prior to 2014 Broadway Premiere] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130205065151/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/174280-Disneys-Aladdin-Will-Play-Toronto-This-Fall-Prior-to-2014-Broadway-Premiere |date=February 5, 2013 }} Retrieved January 22, 2013 It was also announced that the musical would open at London's West End officially in June 2016 at the [[Prince Edward Theatre]], taking the place of the revival of ''[[Miss Saigon]]'', which closed on 27 February 2016. ===''Pinocchio''=== {{main|Pinocchio (2017 play)}}On July 2, 2015, Daily Mail UK announced that a stage version of [[Pinocchio (1940 film)|Disney's Pinocchio]] will be presented by the [[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre]], [[London]] in December 2016. The plot will be the mix of Disney's beloved 1940 film and the [[The Adventures of Pinocchio|original novel]] with the songs, being both used & deleted songs from the movie and other songs from Disney. Creative team includes Tony winner [[John Tiffany]] as the director, [[Enda Walsh]] as playwright, [[Bob Crowley]] as set and costume designer, and [[Steven Hoggett]] as choreographer. A workshop took place in late 2015.http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-3147816/BAZ-BAMIGBOYE-National-Theatre-brings-Pinocchio-life-stage.html#ixzz3emAsufqw The production was delayed due to Tiffany's involvement with ''[[Harry Potter and the Cursed Child]].'' On 19 January 2017, it was announced by Daily Mail columnist Baz Bamigboye that the production would open in December 2017 with Tiffany directing and [[Dennis Kelly]] replacing Walsh as playwright.{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/BazBam/status/822225326071828481|title=Baz Bamigboye on Twitter|newspaper=Twitter|language=en|access-date=2017-01-19}} He also announced that artistic director [[Rufus Norris]] said the National would not take "one cent" from Disney but will use the songs.{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/BazBam/status/822226246503460864|title=Baz Bamigboye on Twitter|newspaper=Twitter|language=en|access-date=2017-01-19}} The production opened in the Lyttleton Theatre at the Royal National Theatre, London on 1 December 2017 running until 10 April 2018. ===''Frozen''=== {{main|Frozen (musical)}}On January 13, 2014, Disney CEO [[Bob Iger]] announced that a [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] stage adaptation of the hit 2013 3D computer-animated musical film ''Frozen'' is in early development stages.Gilbert, Ryan. [http://www.broadway.com/buzz/174011/dreams-do-come-true-disney-confirms-broadway-plans-for-hit-movie-frozen/ "Dreams Do Come True! Disney Confirms Broadway Plans for Hit Movie Frozen"] ''Broadway.com'', January 13, 2014 On February 12, 2015, it was announced that the Broadway musical will be directed by two-time Tony nominee [[Alex Timbers]] and is aiming for the Broadway show to open in 2017.[http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Breaking-News-FROZEN-Aiming-for-the-Stage-by-2017-Alex-Timbers-to-Direct-20150212 Breaking News: FROZEN Aiming for the Stage by 2017; Alex Timbers to Direct!] ''Broadway World'', February 12, 2015 It was announced also that the film's songwriters, [[Robert Lopez]] and [[Kristen Anderson-Lopez]], will write new songs for the show.[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2951555/BAZ-BAMIGBOYE-Red-hot-Cinders-Prince-Charming.html#ixzz3RaeUmyFu] ''Daily Mail'' On February 9, 2016, it was announced that the musical is scheduled to open in spring 2018.{{cite web|last=Cox|first=Gordon|title=‘Frozen’ Musical Sets Broadway Timeline, Creative Team|url=https://variety.com/2016/legit/news/frozen-musical-broadway-dates-1201701188/|publisher=''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]''|accessdate=February 9, 2016|date=February 9, 2016}} A private reading of the stage version of the musical ''Frozen'' was held in May 2016, with Elsa was played by [[Betsy Wolfe]] and Anna was played by Patti Murin.Gans, Andrew. [http://www.playbill.com/article/private-reading-of-frozen-musical-held-in-nyc# "Private Reading of ''Frozen'' Musical Held in NYC"] Playbill, May 20, 2016 On September 27, 2016, [[Michael Grandage]] was selected to take over as the director after Timbers left the production, with [[Christopher Oram]] coming on board as the scenic designer.Hetrick, Adam. [http://www.playbill.com/article/disneys-frozen-gets-tony-winning-director-and-broadway-theatre# "Disney’s 'Frozen' Names Tony-Winning Director and a Broadway Theatre"] Playbill, September 27, 2016 A pre-Broadway tryout ran at the [[Denver Center for the Performing Arts|Buell Theatre]] in Denver, Colorado from August 17 to October 1, 2017. The original Denver and Broadway cast included [[Caissie Levy]] as Elsa, Patti Murin as Anna, [[Jelani Alladin]] as Kristoff, Greg Hildreth as Olaf, and John Riddle as Hans.{{cite web|title=Review Roundup: What Did The Critics Think of Broadway-Bound ''Frozen'' in Denver?|url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Review-Roundup-What-Did-The-Critics-Think-of-Broadway-Bound-FROZEN-in-Denver-Updating-LIVE-20170915|website=BroadwayWorld.com| date=September 15, 2017}} Previews on Broadway at the St. James Theatre began on February 22, 2018, with the official opening on March 22, 2018.{{cite web|title=Breaking: Mark Your Calendar! ''Frozen'' Announces Opening Night on Broadway|date=August 23, 2017|url=https://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Breaking-Mark-Your-Calendar-FROZEN-Announces-Opening-Night-on-Broadway-20170823|website=BroadwayWorld.com}} === Upcoming productions === ====''The Jungle Book''==== Variety stated that there is an "Early-stages project [of] ''Jungle Book'', a tuner version (with songs from the movie) to be written and directed by [[Mary Zimmerman]] ([[Metamorphoses (play)|''Metamorphases'']])."{{cite news| url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118033763 | work=Variety | first=Gordon | last=Cox | title='Alice,' 'Freaky' head to stage | date=March 12, 2011}} A joint mounting of the production occurred at the [[Goodman Theatre]] in Chicago and the [[Huntington Theatre Company|Huntington Theatre]] in Boston in 2013, produced by special arrangement with Disney Theatrical Productions. ==== ''Hercules'' ==== In July 2017, Alan Menken said that he is working on a stage adaptation of the 1997 film, ''[[Hercules (1997 film)|Hercules]]''.BWW News Desk. [http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Will-Disneys-HERCULES-Go-the-Distance-to-Broadway-Alan-Menken-Reveals-Stage-Version-in-the-Works-20170709 "Will Disney's HERCULES Go the Distance to Broadway? Alan Menken Reveals Stage Version in the Works"] Broadway World, July 10, 2017. == Live-action adaptations == ===''Mary Poppins''=== {{main|Mary Poppins (musical)}} Cameron Mackintosh's stage adaptation of ''[[Mary Poppins (film)|Mary Poppins]]'' had its world premiere at the [[Bristol Hippodrome]] starting with previews from September 15, 2004 before officially opening on September 18 for a limited engagement until November 6. The production then moved to the [[Prince Edward Theatre]] on December 15, 2004. It was announced in June 2007 that this production would close on January 12, 2008, after a run of more than three years. To this date it is the only Disney production to premier on the west-end. A UK tour of ''Mary Poppins'' commenced in June 2008 and ended in April 2009. The Broadway production opened on November 16, 2006, following a month of previews in the [[New Amsterdam Theater]]. The Broadway production closed on March 3, 2013 after 2,619 performances.[http://www.broadway.com/buzz/166482/mary-poppins-to-fly-out-of-new-amsterdam-theatre-aladdin-headed-to-broadway/ Mary Poppins to Fly Out of New Amsterdam Theatre; Aladdin Headed to Broadway][http://broadwayworld.com/article/Official-MARY-POPPINS-to-Close-on-March-3-2013-Next-Stop-Regional-Licensing-with-First-8-Productions-Set-20130108 Official: MARY POPPINS to Close on March 3, 2013; Next Stop Regional Licensing with First 8 Productions Set] A North American tour of the show began at Chicago's Cadillac Palace Theatre in March 2009. An Australian production opened at Melbourne's Her Majesty's Theatre in July 2010. A Dutch production opened in April 2010 at the Circus Theater in Scheveningen. A Czech production opened at Brno City Theatre (Městské divadlo Brno) in November 2010. A Mexican production opened at Centro Cultural Telmex on November 14, 2012, with Bianca Marroquín as Mary. An Icelandic production opened in February 2013 at the Reykjavík City Theater. It is the most expensive, difficult and successful show to be produced in Iceland. The [[Austria]]n production opened at [[Vienna]] Ronacher on October 1, 2014. In 2017, The German version will be playing in the Apollo Theatre in Stuttgart. The show will transfer to the Theater an der Elbe in Hamburg in 2018. In September of 2018, it was announced that Mary Poppins would be receiving a [[West End theatre|west-end]] revival to open in late 2019,https://www.londontheatre.co.uk/theatre-news/news/mary-poppins-to-return-to-the-west-end-in-2019 following the closure of [[Aladdin (2011 musical)|Aladdin]] on the west-end. It will re-open at its original theater, the [[Prince Edward Theatre]]. ===''High School Musical''=== {{main|High School Musical on Stage!}} The hit [[Disney Channel]] movie ''[[High School Musical]]'' was adapted for the stage in 2007. It had its world professional premiere at the Theatre of the Stars in [[Atlanta]], Georgia. A US tour began on August 1, 2007 and ended on August 3, 2008. A West End production opened in July for a limited run. High School Musical has performed internationally in [[Japan]], [[Spain]], [[Italy]], [[South Africa]], [[Australia]], [[Netherlands]] and [[South Korea]]. ''High School Musical'' is licensed through [[Music Theatre International]] and has been performed by over 5,000 theaters throughout the world. Currently there is a Full Length version, One-Act Edition and JR one-hour version designed specifically for middle-school aged performances. ===''High School Musical 2''=== {{main|High School Musical 2: On Stage!}} A stage version of the sequel movie ''[[High School Musical 2]]'' was released as a stage version in October 2008. Like the original, the show exists in a full length version, One-Act Edition and a one-hour-long JR version designed for middle-school aged performers and is licensed through [[Music Theatre International]]. ===''Camp Rock''=== A musical version, based on the 2010 film ''[[Camp Rock 2: The Final Jam]]'' and features the songs from the first two ''[[Camp Rock]]'' films. The Gardiner Spring Auditorium in [[Ontario, California|Ontario]], [[California]] on August 5, 2010 and has performed internationally worldwide. The musical is licensed through [[Music Theatre International]]. ===''Newsies''=== {{main|Newsies (musical)}} The show, based on the 1992 film, features a book by [[Harvey Fierstein]] and music by [[Alan Menken]] and [[Jack Feldman (songwriter)|Jack Feldman]]. A reading of the musical was held in New York on December 10, 2010.Rialto Chatter.[http://broadwayworld.com/article/BWW_Exclusive_The_Cast_of_Disneys_NEWSIES_Reading_20101208 "BWW Exclusive: The Cast of Disney's NEWSIES Reading!"] broadwayworld.com, December 8, 2010 The musical premiered at the [[Paper Mill Playhouse]] ([[Millburn, New Jersey]]), in September 2011 with [[Jeff Calhoun (choreographer)|Jeff Calhoun]] as director. "Disney representatives stated that the production was not eyeing a Broadway berth, but is being explored as a property for licensing by professional and amateur groups."Hetrick, Adam.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/147667-Extra-Extra-Disneys-Newsies-Will-Debut-at-Paper-Mill-Playhouse "Extra! Extra! Disney's 'Newsies' Will Debut at Paper Mill Playhouse"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110216082758/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/147667-Extra-Extra-Disneys-Newsies-Will-Debut-at-Paper-Mill-Playhouse |date=February 16, 2011 }} playbill.com, February 14, 2011 However, due to enthusiastic reviews, the show opened on Broadway on March 29, 2012, at the [[Nederlander Theatre]] with an open-ended run.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/156622-Read-All-About-It-Disneys-Newsies-Gets-Spring-2012-Broadway-Engagement Read All About It: Disney's Newsies Gets Spring 2012 Broadway Engagement] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120627023920/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/156622-Read-All-About-It-Disneys-Newsies-Gets-Spring-2012-Broadway-Engagement |date=June 27, 2012 }}[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/143181-Harvey-Fierstein-Is-Librettist-for-Newsies-Musical-With-Songs-by-Menken-and-Feldman Playbill.com Article] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121018094558/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/143181-Harvey-Fierstein-Is-Librettist-for-Newsies-Musical-With-Songs-by-Menken-and-Feldman |date=October 18, 2012 }}[http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/14/extra-extra-newsies-musical-to-open-paper-mill-playhouse-season/ Extra, Extra! ‘Newsies’ Musical to Open Paper Mill Playhouse Season] The show was nominated for eight [[Tony Awards]], including [[Tony Award for Best Musical|Best Musical]], winning [[Tony Award for Best Choreography|Best Choreography]] and [[Tony Award for Best Original Score|Best Original Score]]. ''Newsies'' gave its final Broadway performance on August 24, 2014 while heading out for a national tour in October 2014.{{cite news|last1=Cox|first1=Gordon|title=Disney’s ‘Newsies’ Ends Broadway Run in August|url=https://variety.com/2014/legit/news/newsies-closing-broadway-disney-1201229053/|accessdate=January 7, 2017|work=Variety|date=22 June 2014}} The production was filmed and premiered in cinemas on February 19, 2017. === ''Freaky Friday'' === {{main|Freaky Friday (musical)}} A musical version of the film, with a book by [[Bridget Carpenter]] and a score by Ryan Scott Oliver, was expected to have a "developmental production" at the [[La Jolla Playhouse]] in spring 2012. [[Christopher Ashley]] was named as "likely" to be the director. A developmental lab is set for 31 March through 10 April 2015.[http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Christopher-Ashley-Set-to-Helm-Developmental-Lab-of-Tom-Kitt-Brian-Yorkeys-FREAKY-FRIDAY-Musical-20150204 Christopher Ashley Set to Helm Developmental Lab of Tom Kitt & Brian Yorkey's FREAKY FRIDAY Musical] Broadway World, Retrieved February 4, 2015 Ultimately music and lyrics fell into the hands of [[Tom Kitt (musician)|Tom Kitt]] and [[Brian Yorkey]] of ''If/Then'' and ''Next To Normal'' fame. The premier engagement occurred at Arlington Virginia's [[Signature Theatre (Arlington, Virginia)|Signature Theater]] from October 4 to November 20, 2016, under the direction of Christopher Ashley. The creative team included choreography by Sergio Trujillo, music supervision by Bryan Perri, orchestration by Michael Starobin / Tom Kitt, scenic design by Beowulf Boritt, costume design by Emily Rebholz, lighting by Howell Binkley and sound design by Brian Ronan and Kai Harada. The west coast engagement at the [[La Jolla Playhouse]] (January 31, 2017 - March 19, 2017) reprised most of its Signature Theatre creative team and cast. The Studio Cast Recording album was released by Walt Disney Records on February 10, 2017. ===Upcoming productions=== ==== ''The Muppets'' ==== In 2013, Disney Theatrical revealed that a show based on [[The Muppets]] was in active development and that a 15-minute show had been conducted by [[Thomas Schumacher]] to evaluate the technical components.{{cite news|last=Cox|first=Gordon|title=Disney Theatrical Eyeing Muppets On Stage (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2013/legit/news/disney-theatrical-eyeing-muppets-on-stage-exclusive-1200495467/|accessdate=12 June 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=11 June 2013}} ==== ''The Princess Bride'' ==== Disney plans to adapt William Goldman's ''[[The Princess Bride]]'' into a stage musical.Hetrick, Adam. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/194360-Disney-Remains-Attached-to-The-Princess-Bride-Stage-Adaptation "Disney Remains Attached to ''The Princess Bride'' Stage Adaptation"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140809063001/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/194360-Disney-Remains-Attached-to-The-Princess-Bride-Stage-Adaptation |date=August 9, 2014 }} Playbill.com, August 8, 2014 ==== ''Alice in Wonderland'' ==== {{further|Alice in Wonderland (2010 film)}} Disney Theatrical is already in early talks with Burton and screenwriter [[Linda Woolverton]], to develop the [[Alice in Wonderland (2010 film)|2010 film of the same name]] into a Broadway musical. Woolverton authored the screenplay for Disney's ''[[The Lion King (musical)|The Lion King]]'' and is also the [[Tony Award]]-nominated book writer of ''[[Beauty and the Beast (musical)|Beauty and the Beast]]'', ''[[Aida (musical)|Aida]]'', and ''[[Lestat (musical)|Lestat]]''. Burton will also render the overall designs for the stage musical. Woolverton will adapt her screenplay for the stage production. Neither a composer nor songwriting team has been chosen yet. Robert Jess Roth is set to helm the stage musical that will have choreography by [[Matt West]]. The duo also collaborated on Disney's first Broadway outing: ''Beauty and the Beast''. No casting has been announced. ==== ''Father of the Bride'' ==== {{further|Father of the Bride (1991 film)}} A stage musical version of the film is in development with [[Bartlett Sher]] as expected director.Hetrick, Adam.[http://www.variety.com/article/VR1118033763] Variety.com, March 14, 2011 ==== ''Bedknobs and Broomsticks'' ==== {{further|Bedknobs and Broomsticks (musical)}} A [[Bedknobs and Broomsticks (musical)|stage musical adaptation]] of the film is scheduled to make its world premiere at the Yard at the [[Chicago Shakespeare Theater]] from May 30 to July 28, 2019 as part of its 2018/19 season.{{Cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/article/stage-adaptation-of-disneys-bedknobs-and-broomsticks-sets-chicago-world-premiere|title=Stage Adaptation of Disney’s Bedknobs and Broomsticks Sets Chicago World Premiere|website=Playbill|language=en|access-date=2018-04-01}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.chicagoshakes.com/plays_and_events/explore_season/2018-19-season-announcement|title=Season Announcement|website=Chicago Shakespeare Theater|access-date=2018-04-01}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.bartramandhill.com/blank|title=bartramandhill|website=bartramandhill|language=en|access-date=2018-04-01}} == Other adaptations == ===''King David''=== {{main|King David (musical)}} King David is a musical, sometimes described as a modern oratorio, with a book and lyrics by Tim Rice and music by Alan Menken. The musical is based on Biblical tales from the Books of Samuel and 1 Chronicles, as well as text from David's Psalms. ===''Aida''=== {{main|Aida (musical)}} Aida is a musical based on the opera of the same name by Giuseppe Verdi. It has music by Elton John, lyrics by Tim Rice, and book by Linda Woolverton, Robert Falls, and David Henry Hwang, and was originally produced by Walt Disney Theatrical. ===''On the Record''=== {{main|On the Record (musical)}} Debuting in November 2004, the show brought together sixty classic Disney songs from 1930 right up to 2004. They are woven together loosely by a storyline which is set in a recording studio with young (and old) performers using the songs to express their moods and the interrelationships among the characters they portray. The show played at the National Theatre in Washington D.C., as well as other theatres on a national tour. ===''Peter and the Starcatcher''=== {{main|Peter and the Starcatcher}} Disney Theatrical Productions and [[La Jolla Playhouse]] (California) adapted ''Peter and the Starcatchers'', which is a prequel to the [[Peter Pan]] story, into a play with music. The new play is written by [[Rick Elice]], co-directed by [[Roger Rees]] and Alex Timbers, and is based on the novel by [[Dave Barry]] and [[Ridley Pearson]]. It was produced as part of La Jolla Playhouse's Page to Stage program, and ran from February 13, 2009 through March 8, 2009.Jones, Kenneth.[http://www.playbill.com/news/article/119891.html "Can He Fly? Disney and La Jolla Will Test Wings of Starcatchers — a Peter Pan Prequel"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080731234159/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/119891.html |date=July 31, 2008 }}, playbill.com, July 28, 2008 An [[Off Broadway]] production opened at New York Theatre Workshop [http://theater.nytimes.com/2011/03/10/theater/reviews/peter-and-the-starcatcher-at-theater-workshop-review.html March 2011] It moved to Broadway on April 15, 2012. The show ended its Broadway run on January 20, 2013, and reopened Off-Broadway once again at [[New World Stages]] in March 2013. ===''Shakespeare in Love''=== {{main|Shakespeare in Love (play)}} In November 2013, Disney Theatrical Productions, announced plans to mount a stage version of the film ''[[Shakespeare in Love]]'' in London, with Sonia Friedman Productions as co-producer.{{cite news|last1=Cox|first1=Gordon|title=Disney Theatrical Gets Busy with ‘Shakespeare in Love’ and ‘Newsies’|url=https://variety.com/2013/legit/news/disney-theatrical-gets-busy-with-shakespeare-in-love-and-newsies-1200826921/|accessdate=July 11, 2014|publisher=Variety|date=November 13, 2013}} The West End production played at the [[Noël Coward Theatre]], with the world premiere scheduled for July 23, 2014.{{cite news|last1=Cox|first1=Gordon|title=First Look: ‘Shakespeare in Love’ on the West End|url=https://variety.com/gallery/shakespeare-in-love-west-end-photos/|accessdate=July 11, 2014|publisher=Variety|date=July 7, 2014}} Based on the screenplay by [[Marc Norman]] and [[Tom Stoppard]], it has been adapted for the stage by [[Lee Hall (playwright)|Lee Hall]]. The production is directed by [[Declan Donnellan]] and designed by [[Nick Ormerod]], the driving force behind the noted theatre company, [[Cheek by Jowl]]. However, it was announced that the production would close on 18 April 2015. ==TV special== The television special ''Backstage with Disney On Broadway: Celebrating 20 Years'' aired in December 2014. ==See also== * [[Disney on Ice]] * [[Disney Live|Disney Live!]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Walt Disney Studios}} {{Disney Theatrical Productions}} [[Category:Disney Theatrical Group| ]] [[Category:Walt Disney Theatrical| ]] [[Category:Theatre companies in New York City]] [[Category:Entertainment companies based in New York City]] [[Category:American companies established in 1993]] [[Category:Entertainment companies established in 1993]] [[Category:Media companies established in 1993]] [[Category:1993 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Musicals based on films]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2017}} {{Use British English|date=February 2017}} The '''Ebor Festival''' is a four-day race meeting held at [[York Racecourse]] in [[York]], England, each August. The 2017 Ebor Festival is due to take place from 23 to 26 August<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.yorkracecourse.co.uk/racing-fixtures.html|title=2017 Fixtures & Pricing|website=www.yorkracecourse.co.uk|access-date=2017-07-20}}</ref>.
The Ebor festival was established in 1843 with the first running of the Ebor Handicap.
Each of the four days has feature races:
*Wednesday is called Juddmonte International Day and features the [[International Stakes|Juddmonte International]], the [[Great Voltigeur Stakes]] and the [[Acomb Stakes]]. *Thursday is Ladies' Day and features the [[Lowther Stakes]] and the [[Yorkshire Oaks]]. *Friday is Nunthorpe Day and features the [[Nunthorpe Stakes]], the [[Gimcrack Stakes]] and the [[Strensall Stakes]]. *Saturday is Ebor Day and features the [[Ebor Handicap]] and the [[Lonsdale Cup]].
The 2008 Ebor Festival was abandoned after wet weather left the course waterlogged and unfit for racing. It was the first time in the event's history that the entire card had to be scrapped due to bad weather.
As one of the last major race meetings of the [[flat racing|flat season]], it attracts racegoers from all over the UK and overseas.
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120126075407/https://yorkracecourse.co.uk/racing/fixtures/welcome-to-yorkshire-ebor-festival_37 York Racecourse Ebor festival page] *[http://www.ebor-festival.com/ The Ebor Festival website] *[http://www.ebor-festival.com/category/ebor-festival-news/ebor-festival-dates-201507270001/ The Ebor Festival dates and full schedule]

{{one source|date=August 2016}} '''Factitious diarrhea''' is a condition in which a person deliberately produces [[diarrhea]], most commonly by surreptitious [[laxative]] abuse.
These people tend to have persistent and unexplained watery diarrhea that is high in volume and frequency and, despite extensive evaluation, the cause may remain unknown. Many cases may mimic [[inflammatory bowel disease]] or [[malabsorption syndromes]].<ref>Oster JR, Materson BJ, Rogers AI. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7234824 Laxative abuse syndrome] Am J Gastroenterol. 1980 Nov;74(5):451-8. {{PMID|7234824}}</ref> [[Bowel movements]] are generally about 10 to 20 a day and may be especially associated with nocturnal movements. Factitious diarrhea is most often seen in men and sometimes women of high [[socioeconomic]] status and many are employed in the medical field.
[[Melanosis coli]] is a frequent find in long-standing factitious diarrhea.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Cash|first1=Brooks D.|title=Curbside Consultation of the Colon: 49 Clinical Questions|date=2008|publisher=SLACK Incorporated|isbn=9781556428319|page=51|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y0hV1_irdpkC&dq=Factitious+diarrhea+melanosis+coli&source=gbs_navlinks_s|accessdate=17 January 2018|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Wald|first1=Arnold|title=UpToDate|url=https://www.uptodate.com/contents/factitious-diarrhea-clinical-manifestations-diagnosis-and-management|website=www.uptodate.com|accessdate=17 January 2018}}</ref> It demonstrates [[hyperpigmentation]] of the [[colon (organ)|colon]] with white [[lymph nodes]] showing through on [[colonoscopy]]. An alternative means of diagnosis is by detecting [[pigment]] in [[macrophages]] of the [[lamina propria]].

[[Image:Spoleto Cathedral.jpg|thumb|200px|Cathedral of [[Spoleto Cathedral|Santa Maria Assunta]] in Spoleto]] :''For the Spoleto Festival USA, see [[Spoleto Festival USA]] and for the Spoleto Festival Melbourne see [[Melbourne International Arts Festival]]''.
The '''''Festival dei Due Mondi''''' '''(Festival of the Two Worlds)''' is an annual summer music and [[opera]] festival held each June to early July in [[Spoleto]], Italy, since its founding by composer [[Gian Carlo Menotti]] in 1958. It features a vast array of concerts, opera, dance, drama, visual arts and roundtable discussions on science.
The "Two Worlds" in the name of the festival comes from Gian Carlo Menotti's intention to have the worlds of American and European culture facing each other in his event; this concept would then be strengthened by the fact that it was held in conjunction with its "twin", the [[Spoleto Festival USA]] held annually in May/June in [[Charleston, South Carolina]]. That twinning lasted some 15 years and, after growing disputes between the Menotti family and the board of Spoleto Festival USA, in the early 1990s a separation occurred. Under Menotti's direction in 1986, a third installment in the Spoleto Festival series was held in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]]. Melbourne's Spoleto Festival changed its name to the [[Melbourne International Arts Festival|Melbourne International Festival of the Arts]] in 1990.
Following Menotti's death in 2007, changes occurred in the administration with the result that the Italian Minister of Cultural Affairs appointed a new Artistic Administrator who continues to run the Festival.
==The Italian Festival's location and activities== Because Spoleto was a small town, where real estate and other goods and services were at the time relatively inexpensive, and also because there are two indoor theatres, a Roman theatre, and many other spaces, it was chosen by Menotti as the venue for an arts festival. It is also fairly close to Rome, with good rail connections.{{cn|date=July 2018}}
==Changes in administration== Following Menotti's death in February 2007, the city administrations of Spoleto and Charleston started talks to re-unite the two festivals, which resulted in the Mayor of Spoleto, Massimo Brunini, attending the opening ceremony of Spoleto Festival USA in May 2008.
However, at the time of the 2007 Festival, the President and Artistic Director was Menotti's adopted son, [[Francis Menotti|Francis "Chip" Menotti]] and, in the fall of 2007, the Italian Minister of Cultural Affairs, [[Francesco Rutelli]]—after unsuccessful negotiations with Menotti—removed him from his position<ref>Wakin, ''New York Times''</ref> and named Giorgio Ferrara new artistic director of the festival. This has resulted in continuing controversy between representatives of the "old" and "new" managements of the Festival, as exemplified by the maintenance of a website critical of the former management, which can be seen below.
==Prominent artists who have been involved== {{Div col|colwidth=30em|rules=yes}} *[[Luchino Visconti]] *[[Eduardo De Filippo]] *[[Rudolf Nureyev]] *[[Carla Fracci]] *[[Thomas Schippers]] *[[Romolo Valli]] *[[Ken Russell]] *[[Nino Rota]] *[[Roman Polanski]] *[[Ezra Pound]] *[[Vittorio Gassman]] *[[Arnoldo Foà]] *[[Luciano Pavarotti]] *[[Joaquin Cortes]] *[[Ralph Farris]] *[[Al Pacino]] {{Div col end}}

{{COI|date=June 2008}} {{Primary sources|date=February 2016}} The '''GeoWeb Conference''' focuses on the emergence of a true geographic dimension to the [[World Wide Web]], and on the impact of [[Internet]] technologies on the acquisition, processing and visualization of geographic information. [[Geoweb]] is a conference of ideas and networking – how can we work together to build a global, integrated and inclusive model of our planet.
The GeoWeb Conference attracts senior decision-makers, industry leaders and technologists that are interested in the convergence of web technologies, [[XML]], [[web services]] and [[GIS]]. The GeoWeb Conference is open to all businesses, academic institutions and governments that are interested in: the development of new Geoweb technology; the impact of the Geoweb on businesses and government policies; the emergence of new business models for the Geoweb; and the multitude of applications associate with the new Geoweb technology.
==2008 Conference== The 7th Annual GeoWeb Conference took place in Vancouver, Canada from July 21-25, 2008 at the Morris J. Wosk Centre for Dialogue. The first and second days of the conference were composed of 16 workshops which included hands-on demonstrations and real world case studies.
The last 3 days of the conference included three Keynote Speakers which were: Dr. William B. Gail of [[Microsoft Virtual Earth]]; Michael T. Jones of [[Google]]; and Alex Miller of [[Environmental Systems Research Institute|ESRI]] Canada Ltd.; three Invited Speakers were: Dr. [[Michael Goodchild]], of the University of California, Santa Barbara; Dr. Michael Kay of Saxonica; and Kimon G. Onuma, FAIA of Onuma, Inc.; 3 panel discussions; a vendor exhibit and the presentation of the 1st GeoWeb Student Contest winners.
==2007 Conference== The 6th Annual GeoWeb Conference took place July 23-27, 2007 at the Morris J. Wosk Centre for Dialogue in Vancouver, British Columbia. The conference provided two days of workshops, three days of technical presentations, and featured keynote speakers [[Jack Dangermond]] of ESRI, Michael Jones of [[Google Earth]], and Geoff Zeiss of [[Autodesk]], a guest speaker [[Vinton Cerf]] "the Father of the [[Internet]]" and plenary speaker Vincent Tao of [[Microsoft]].
==2006 Conference== The 5th Annual GeoWeb Conference took place July 24-28, 2006 at the Morris J. Wosk Centre for Dialogue in Vancouver, British Columbia. The conference provided two days of workshops, three days of technical presentations and featured keynote speakers Steven Lawler of Virtual Earth [[Microsoft]] Corporation, Kurt Cagle of [[Mercurial Communications]], and Michael Jones of [[Google Earth]] and Plenary Speakers Xavier Lopez of [[Oracle Corporation]] and Gary Lang of [[Autodesk, Inc.]]
==2005 Conference (formerly GML Days)== The 4th Annual [[Geography Markup Language|GML]] Days Conference took place July 18-22, 2005 at the Morris J. Wosk Centre for Dialogue in Vancouver, British Columbia. The conference provided two days of workshops, three days of technical presentations and featured keynote speakers James Bryce Clark of Oasis, Leslie Armstrong of [[Federal Geographic Data Committee]], George Moon of [[MapInfo Corporation|MapInfo]] and Ron Lake of Galdos Systems Inc.
==2004 Conference (formerly GML Dev Days 2004)== The 3rd Annual Conference (formerly known as [[Geography Markup Language|GML]] Dev Days 2004) took place July 25-29 at the Morris J. Wosk Centre for Dialogue in Vancouver, British Columbia. The conference provided two days of workshops, three days of technical presentations and featured keynote speakers Preetha Pulusani of Integraph Mapping and GeoSpatial Solutions, Xavier Lopez of [[Oracle Corporation]], Clemens Portele of Interactive Instruments GmbH, and Ron Lake of Galdos Systems Inc.
==2003 Conference (formerly GML Dev Days 2003)== The 2nd Annual Conference (formerly known as [[Geography Markup Language|GML]] Dev Days 2003) took place July 20-24 at the Morris J. Wosk Centre for Dialogue in Vancouver, British Columbia. The conference provided two days of workshops, three days of technical presentations and featured keynote speakers Kurt Buehler of OGC, Pierre Lemire of [[Autodesk]], Inc., and Clemens Portele of Interactive Instruments GmbH.
==2002 Conference (formerly GML Dev Days 2002)== The 1st Annual Conference (formerly known as [[Geography Markup Language|GML]] Dev Days 2002) took place July 22-26 at the Morris J. Wosk Centre for Dialogue in Vancouver, British Columbia. The conference provided two days of workshops, three days of technical presentations and featured keynote speakers Ron Lake of Galdos Systems Inc., Xavier Lopez of [[Oracle Corporation]] and Ed Parsons of [[Ordnance Survey]].
==External links== *[http://www.geowebconference.org GeoWeb Conference site] *[http://www.galdosinc.com Galdos Systems Inc. Conference Organizer] *[http://www.gita.org Geospatial Information & Technology Association (GITA) Conference Supporter]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Geoweb Conference}} [[Category:Geographic information systems]] [[Category:Computer conferences]]

'''The Golden Microphone''' ({{lang-tr|Altın Mikrofon}}) contest was a music contest annually held between 1965−1968 in [[Turkey]]. It was organized by the newspaper ''[[Hürriyet]]''. In 1960s, most of the Turkish popular music melodies were either songs from west Europe with Turkish lyrics or traditional Turkish folk melodies played with western instruments.<ref>[http://hurarsiv.hurriyet.com.tr/goster/ShowNew.aspx?id=104398 Hürriyet newspaper archive {{tr icon}}]</ref> The goal of the contest was to encourage the development of [[Turkish pop music|popular Turkish music]] either by new compositions or by using domestic sources. More formally, Hürriyet announced the goal of the contest as "Redirecting Turkish music using technique and style of the western music as well as the instruments of the western music" <ref>[http://heydergisi.blogcu.com/altin-mikrofon-yarismalari-tarihcesi-1965-1968/9913462 Hey blog (Hürriyet sponsored periodical {{tr icon}})]</ref> ==Winners == {| class="sortable wikitable" !Year !Rank !Group !Title |- |rowspan="3"|1965 |bgcolor=gold|1st||Yıldırım Gürses||''Gençliğe Veda'' |- |bgcolor=silver |2nd||Mavi Işıklar||''Helvacı'' |- |bgcolor=cc9966|3rd||[[Silüetler]]||''Kaşık Havası'' |- |rowspan=3|1966 |bgcolor=gold|1st||Silüetler||''Lorke Lorke'' |- |bgcolor=silver|2nd|| Mavi Işıklar||''Çayır Çimen Geze Geze'' |- |bgcolor=cc9966|3rd||Selçuk Alagöz||''Ararım'' |- |rowspan=3|1967 |bgcolor=gold|1st||Mavi Çocuklar||''Develi Daylar'' |- |bgcolor=silver|2nd||[[Cem Karaca]]||''Emrah'' |- |bgcolor=cc9966|3rd|| Rana Alagöz||''Konya Kabağı'' |- |rowspan=3|1968 |bgcolor=gold|1st||[[TPAO Batman]]||''Meşelidir Enginde Dağlar'' |- |bgcolor=silver|2nd||Haramiler||''Arpa Buğday Daneler'' |- |bgcolor=cc9966|3rd|| [[Moğollar]]||''[[Ilgaz Mountains#In popular music|Ilgaz]]'' |}<ref name="Anadolu">[http://www.anadolupop.com/web/altinmikrofon/sonuc.html Results from Anadolu pop {{tr icon}}]</ref> ==Later years == Altın Mikrofon was a milestone in Turkish music. Although Hürriyet gave up organizing the contest after 1968, two other newspapers tried to continue: ''[[Günaydın (newspaper)|Günaydın]]'' in 1972 and Saklambaç in 1979. But these later contests unlike the earlier contests, didn’t attracted much attention and they too gave up. The results of these were as follows: {| class="sortable wikitable" !Year !Rank !Group !Title |- |rowspan="3"|1972 |bgcolor=gold|1st||Edip Akbayram||''Kükredi Çimenler'' |- |bgcolor=silver |2nd||Salim Dündar||''Bir dost bulamadım'' |- |bgcolor=cc9966|3rd||Ömer Aysan||''Mış mış'' |- |1979 |bgcolor=gold|1st||Ünal Büyükgönenç||''Dışarda Kar yağıyor'' |} <ref name="Anadolu"/>
==References== <references /> ==External links== * [http://tr.myspace.com/yildirimgurses/music/songs/gen-li-e-veda-46974913 1965 winner] * [https://industriaturca.blogs.sapo.pt/75894.html 1966 winner] * [http://www.klipx.org/muzik-dinle/51677.html# 1967 winner] * [http://alkislarlayasiyorum.com/icerik/8238/tpao-batman-orkestrasi-meselidir-engin-de-daglar-1968 1968 winner] [[Category:Music festivals in Turkey]] [[Category:Music competitions]] [[Category:1965 establishments in Turkey]] [[Category:1979 disestablishments in Turkey]] [[Category:Turkish music awards]] [[Category:Pop music awards]]

{{about|the 1979 musical|the 1944 play|I Remember Mama (play)|the 1948 feature film|I Remember Mama (film)|the 1949 TV series|Mama (TV series)}} {{Infobox Musical |name= I Remember Mama |subtitle= |image= RememberMama.jpg |image_size= 200px |caption= 1985 Studio Recording |music= [[Richard Rodgers]] |lyrics= [[Martin Charnin]]
[[Raymond Jessel]] |book= [[Thomas Meehan (writer)|Thomas Meehan]] |basis= Memoir by [[Kathryn Forbes]]
''[[Mama's Bank Account]]'' |productions= 1979 [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] |awards= }} '''''I Remember Mama''''' is a [[musical theatre|musical]] with a book by [[Thomas Meehan (writer)|Thomas Meehan]], lyrics by [[Martin Charnin]] and [[Raymond Jessel]], and music by [[Richard Rodgers]]. The musical ran on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] in 1979. ==Origins== ''I Remember Mama'' originated as a [[memoir]] by [[Kathryn Forbes]] titled ''Mama's Bank Account''. It was adapted for the stage by [[John Van Druten]] as a [[I Remember Mama (play)|play]], which ran on Broadway from 1944 to 1946.[http://www.ibdb.com/production.php?id=1586 "I Remember Mama Broadway, 1944-1946"] Internet Broadway Database, accessed March 24, 2012 [[Richard Rodgers]] and [[Oscar Hammerstein II]] were the producers. It was filmed in [[1948 in film|1948]], and served as the basis for a 1950s television series, titled ''[[Mama (TV series)|Mama]]''. Every incarnation basically was the same, a series of heartwarming [[vignette (literature)|vignettes]] centering on a family of [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[immigrants]] living in [[San Francisco]] in the early 20th Century. At its core is the oldest daughter, Katrin, who yearns to be a published writer and conspires to meet renowned author Dame Sybil Fitzgibbons, a guest at the Fairmont Hotel, for professional advice and guidance. It is through Katrin's eyes the struggles, hopes, and dreams of the Hansens unfold. ==Production== The musical adaptation was beset with problems from the beginning. Rodgers and Charnin had composed a full score before the libretto was written, so they ended up having to replace a significant number of songs throughout rehearsals. The original director, Charnin, was replaced by [[Cy Feuer]] after tryouts in Philadelphia, with producer [[Alexander H. Cohen]] saying "they had to go 'for radical surgery' ".Hyland, William. [https://books.google.com/books?id=ZSPfjWK_b2YC&pg=PA306&dq=%22Ullmann%22+%22I+Remember+Mama%22+Rodgers&hl=en#v=onepage&q=%22Ullmann%22%20%22I%20Remember%20Mama%22%20Rodgers&f=false "I Remember Mama"], ''Richard Rodgers'' (1998), (books.google.com), Yale University Press, {{ISBN|0-300-07115-9}}, p. 306-8 The original choreographer, [[Graciela Daniele]], was replaced by [[Danny Daniels]].Block, Geoffrey. [https://books.google.com/books?id=YJxYg6ctHtMC&pg=PA241&dq=%22Ullmann%22+%22I+Remember+Mama%22+Rodgers&hl=en#v=onepage&q=%22Ullmann%22%20%22I%20Remember%20Mama%22%20Rodgers&f=false "I Remember Mama"] ''Richard Rodgers'' (2003), (books.google.com), Yale University Press, {{ISBN|0-300-09747-6}}, p.241 The musical, produced by Alexander H. Cohen and [[Hildy Parks]] opened on Broadway on May 31, 1979 at the [[Majestic Theatre (Broadway)|Majestic Theatre]], where it closed on September 2 after 108 performances and 40 previews. Directed by [[Cy Feuer]], the opening cast featured [[Liv Ullmann]], [[George Hearn]], [[Dolores Wilson]], and [[George S. Irving]]. The spectacular and clever set was designed by the late David Mitchell (of "Annie" fame). ==Reception== By 1979, Broadway audiences had become accustomed to edgier musicals such as ''[[Sweeney Todd (musical)|Sweeney Todd]]'' and ''[[Evita (musical)|Evita]]''. Critics found ''Mama'' to be old-fashioned and corny, and all were quick to describe the musically disinclined Ullmann as miscast. ''[[The New York Times]]'' reviewer wrote: "At the end of its much-postponed and choppy progress...this big and expensive musical had buried most of the strengths it possesses under a mass of cliches and a pervading, forced cuteness.... Miss Ullman is unsuited to it."Eder, Richard. "Theater Review", ''The New York Times'', June 1, 1979, p. C3 Show business insiders dubbed the Rodgers' production "I Dismembered Mama." A different musical version starring Celeste Holm played several regional theaters and was better received by audiences and reviewers alike but was prevented from coming to New York. Advance box office sales, particularly for [[wikt:matinée|matinée]] performances, had been strong enough to keep the show alive in its early weeks, but attendance quickly dropped in numbers dramatic enough to warrant closing. It was Rodgers' last musical. An [[cast album|original cast album]] was never recorded, but a studio recording with Hearn and Irving reprising their stage roles and [[Sally Ann Howes]] replacing Ullmann was released in 1985. ==Canadian premiere== The first Canadian production of the musical came in 2004. Produced by the Toronto Civic Light Opera Company, the production was designed and directed by Joe Cascone. Starring Caroline Moro-Dalicandro as Mama, David Haines as Papa, Larry Westlake as Uncle Chris and Andrea Strayer as Katrin. This production took a few minor liberties with the script and score, but was a very big success for the company. The show ran over the Christmas season and garnered rave reviews and tremendous audience reception. Quoted one member of the original Broadway production staff, "The show is a hit at last!"http://www.CivicLightOperaCompany.com ==Song list== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ;Act I * I Remember Mama * A Little Bit More * A Writer Writes at Night * Ev'ry Day (Comes Something Beautiful) * The Hardangerfjord * You Could Not Please Me More * Uncle Chris * Easy Come, Easy Go * It Is Not the End of the World {{col-break}} ;Act II * Mama Always Makes it Better * Lars, Lars * Fair Trade * It's Going to Be Good to Be Gone * Time * I Remember Mama (Reprise) {{col-end}} ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *{{cite book |last=Mandelbaum |first=Ken |authorlink=Ken Mandelbaum |title=[[Not Since Carrie|Not Since Carrie: Forty Years of Broadway Musical Flops]] |publisher=[[St. Martin's Press]] |year=1991}} ==External links== *[http://www.ibdb.com/production.php?id=3795 Internet Broadway Database Listing] *[http://www.rnh.com/show/55/I-Remember-Mama Listing with history and production information at RNH official site] *[http://guidetomusicaltheatre.com/shows_i/i_remember_mama.htm ''I Remember Mama'' Summary, Story, and Musical Numbers at guidetomusicaltheatre.com] {{DEFAULTSORT:I Remember Mama}} [[Category:Broadway musicals]] [[Category:1979 musicals]] [[Category:Musicals inspired by real-life events]] [[Category:Musicals by Thomas Meehan (writer)]] [[Category:Norwegian-American culture in California]] [[Category:Works about Norwegian-American culture]] [[Category:Compositions by Richard Rodgers]]

{{Infobox Film Festival | name = International Film Festival and Forum on Human Rights | founded = 2002, [[Leo Kaneman]] | awardsgiven = Grand Prix, Fiction and Human Rights, World Organization Against Torture, Youth Jury | directors = Isabelle Gattiker (since 2015) | date = Annually, in March (during the UN Human Rights Council) | location = [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]] | language = International | website = http://www.fifdh.org }} The '''International Film Festival and Forum on Human Rights''' (FIFDH) is one of the most important international events dedicated to cinema and human rights, located in the heart of [[Geneva]], "international capital of human rights". The inspiration and impetus behind the International Film Festival and Forum on Human Rights came from human rights defenders active in NGO’s, filmmakers, media representatives and the University of Geneva. The FIFDH coincides with the UN Human Rights Council’s main session. This simultaneous event makes the Festival a Free Platform for discussion and debates on a wide variety of topics concerning human rights.<ref>http://www.fifdh.org/site/le-festival</ref> It was created by [[Léo Kaneman]] and co-founded by Yäel Reinharz Hazan, Pierre Hazan and Isabelle Gattiker in November 2002. Its first edition took place in March 2003.<ref>http://www.cooperationinternationalegeneve.ch/fr/11-me-dition-du-fifdh-rencontre-avec-son-directeur-l-o-kanenman</ref>
== Film festival ==
With its concept « A film, A subject, A debate », the FIFDH aims to underline human rights violations through films and debates, in the presence of filmmakers, human rights defenders, politicians and recognized specialists. Its programme is designed to increase public awareness and inspire people to reinforce their commitment to universal values. In 2014, more than 25’000 visitors attended the Festival’s screenings and debates.<ref>http://www.ge.ch/solidarite-internationale/newsletter/2014-05/fifdh.asp</ref>
== An international forum on human rights == As a genuine Forum on Human Rights, the Festival informs and firmly denounces violations of civil, political, economic, social and cultural rights wherever they occur. In the heart of Geneva, the « human rights international capital », the FIFDH is a relay for human rights defenders active on the field. It offers debates as well as unscreened films and solidarity actions.<ref>http://fr.euronews.com/2014/03/17/fifdh-cinema-et-droits-humains/</ref>
== Personalities present at the festival == Present at the precedent editions were, among others : [[Edward Snowden]]<ref>http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/europe/Edward-Snowden-says-he-would-like-to-return-to-Geneva/articleshow/46478619.cms</ref> (via Skype) [[Anna Politkovskaïa]],<ref>http://www.infosud.org/spip.php?page=article&id_article=106</ref> [[Shirin Ebadi]],<ref>http://www.hebdo.ch/succegraves_dun_protest_festival_20177_.html</ref> [[Carla Del {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2011}} {{Infobox holiday |holiday_name = Jeûne genevois (Genevan fast) |type = |image = |imagesize = |caption = |official_name = |nickname = |duration = 1 day |frequency = annual |observedby = [[Canton of Geneva]], Switzerland |litcolor = |longtype = |significance = |begins = |ends = |date = Thursday following the first Sunday of September |date{{LASTYEAR}} = {{Weekday after date|{{LASTYEAR}}|September|4|Thursday|j F}} |date{{CURRENTYEAR}} = {{Weekday after date|{{CURRENTYEAR}}|September|4|Thursday|j F}} |date{{NEXTYEAR}} = {{Weekday after date|{{NEXTYEAR}}|September|4|Thursday|j F}} |date{{#time:Y|+2 years}} = {{Weekday after date|{{#time:Y|+2 years}}|September|4|Thursday|j F}} |celebrations = |observances = |relatedto = }} '''Jeûne genevois''' (meaning Genevan fast) is a public holiday in the [[Cantons of Switzerland|canton]] of [[Canton of Geneva|Geneva]], Switzerland which occurs on the Thursday following the first Sunday of September. It dates back to the 16th century.
==Background== In Europe, beginning in the 15th century, people [[fasting|fasted]] as a way of remembering [[famine]]s, plagues and wars. The [[Tagsatzung|Swiss Federal Diet]]s of 1480 and 1483 talked about national [[Fast Day]]s of penitence and thanksgiving but in the end, left these to the cantons. With no [[Federation|federal]] law, fast days became pilgrimages, processions, litanies and fasts.<ref>Catherine Santschi, ''La mémoire des Suisses'', Association de l'Encyclopédie de Genève, 1991</ref>
In 1522 [[Huldrych Zwingli]], who helped stir [[Protestantism|Protestant]] [[Reformation in Switzerland]], said fasting laws were only human notions which had nothing to do with the [[Holy Writ]].<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | title = Ulrich Zwingli | encyclopedia = [[Catholic Encyclopedia]] | volume = XV | publisher=The Encyclopedia Press | year = 1913 | url = http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/15772a.htm}}</ref> Nonetheless, the plagues of [[Basle]] (1541) and [[Berne]] (1565 and 1577) were followed by days of [[penitence]] and [[fasting]], asking God for [[clemency]] and mercy.<ref>Olivier Fatio, ''Le Jeûne genevois, réalité et mythe'' (BSHAG<sub>14</sub>), 1971.</ref>
===Began before St. Bartholomew's Day massacre=== [[Geneva]] was a cradle of Protestantism and the [[Protestant Reformation|Reformation]]. There was a Geneva-wide fast in the beginning of October 1567 as a sign of friendship with Protestants undergoing [[religious persecution|persecution]] in [[Lyon]], France and this was most likely the first ''Jeûne genevois'' (Genevan fast). Five years later, news of the [[St. Bartholomew's Day massacre]] and the slaughter of several thousand [[Huguenot]]s beginning on 24 August 1572 triggered a fast throughout Geneva on the following 3 September, which could be why the date of later yearly fasts was shifted back by almost a month.
By 1640, through sway of the reformed cantons, the fast had become yearly and was carried on even after the Genevan revolution of 1792. ''Jeûne genevois'' later became a patriotic holiday, symbolizing both Geneva's proud identity and its [[Protestantism]]. By the beginning of the [[Helvetic Republic]] folklore had thoroughly linked ''Jeûne genevois'' with the widely remembered St. Bartholomew's Day massacre and fasting in Geneva as the slaughter of whole Protestant families carried on throughout France.<ref>[http://www.geneve.ch/FAO/2002/20020904.asp FAO de Genève] 250th Year, # 102</ref>
==In Geneva== In 1831 the Federal Diet decreed a ''Jeûne Fédéral'' (federal fast) for all cantons, fixing the date at 8 September. This was later made the third Sunday in September but for Geneva, which fixed the day of its own ''Jeûne genevois''.
In 1869 Geneva decreed that the holiday was no longer official, but ''Jeûne genevois'' was celebrated unofficially until 1965, slowly losing its religious significance. On 1 August 1966 it was again declared a public holiday and the date fixed as the Thursday following the first Sunday of September.
The religious fasting of ''Jeûne genevois'' is not widely followed. Banks and post offices along with many shops, restaurants and bars close for the day. However, unlike [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]] in the U.S., which also falls on a Thursday, a four-day weekend is not usually taken and most businesses are open on Friday.
===Plum pie=== [[File:Tarte pruneaux 2.jpg|right|250px|thumb|Plum pie, a symbol of Jeûne genevois]] Plum pie<ref>Geneva lunch.com, ''[http://genevalunch.com/savouring-switzerland/2010/09/09/plum-pie-that-annual-geneva-favourite-french-lesson-included/ : Plum pie recipe: that annual Geneva favourite]'', 9 September 2010</ref>(''tarte aux pruneaux'') is often served as dessert in Geneva homes on ''Jeûne genevois''. Any knowledge as to how this tradition began seems to have been lost, although it may have come about as a means to allow women and housekeepers a way to spend the day in prayer, having cooked plum pies the day before (area plums being in season), with these plum pies the only food eaten in many Geneva households on ''Jeûne genevois''.<ref>ge.ch, ''[http://www.ge.ch/fao/2007/20070905.asp Jeûne genevois: qu'est-ce qui se cache derrière la fameuse tarte aux pruneaux?]'', 5 September 2007, retrieved 9 September 2009</ref>
